alert.note: Alert for San Miguel (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 12 at 3:52PM MDT until September 12 at 6:30PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE HERMITS PEAK AND CALF CANYON BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 630 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR NORTHWESTERN SAN MIGUEL COUNTY... At 352 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar had ended. However, runoff from earlier heavy rain will continue through the afternoon hours. Flash flooding is likely ongoing. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact the Tecolote Creek and Gallinas River drainage areas including Cabo Lucero Creek, Canon Mesteno, Ojitos Frios Creek, Tecolote Creek, Porvenir Canyon, Arroyo Pecos, Agua Zarca and Vegosa Creek. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Las Vegas, El Porvenir, Montezuma, Storrie Lake State Park, Mineral Hill, Gallinas, San Geronimo, San Pablo and Ojitos Frios. This includes the following highways... State Road 518 between Mile Markers 1 and 10. State Road 283 between Mile Markers 1 and 12...and near Mile Marker 14. Interstate 25 between Mile Markers 344 and 348. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 1 and 14. This includes the following low water crossings... West Las Vegas High School, Mills Bridge and Valencia Street. This includes the following recreation areas... E.V. Long Campground, El Porvenir Campground and Storrie Lake State Park. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the HPCC fire burn area. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.
